intro: Pedicularis crenata var. typica, commonly known as the serrated lousewort, is a flowering plant native to the mountainous regions of Europe and Asia. It belongs to the family Orobanchaceae, commonly known as the broomrape family, and is characterized by its parasitic growth habit. The plant typically has hairy stems and leaves with a serrated margin, and its flowers are usually pink or purple, arranged in a spike-like inflorescence. It thrives in moist, acidic soils and is often found in alpine or subalpine habitats. Due to its specialized ecological requirements, it is considered a rare and endangered species in many areas.
